Message.Title: Subject
Message.Msg: iPad Mini Sales Overtaking iPad 2, iPad with Retina Display; Mini Sales Faster Than Apple Expected The iPad Mini's sales are surpassing the two regular sized iPads in sales, according to latest figures. The iPad Mini made its debut in late October with the iPad with Retina Display, or iPad 4, but it appears the iPad Mini is cannibalizing the sales of the 9.7-inch iPads, according to a report by NDP DisplaySearch. The report noted Apple planned to sell 40 million units of the iPad Mini and 60 million units of the iPads. "However, the reality seems to be the reverse, as the iPad mini has been more popular than the iPad," explains David Hsieh of DisplaySearch. Hsieh added that Apple now plans to sell 55 million units of the iPad Mini while the 9.7-inch iPads will sell 33 million units © 2013 Latinos Post. All rights reserved. Message.Title: Reason for low PE
Message.Msg: The low PE is based on past earnings. Topic.Title: Apple has already reached its peak of quality and inovation,

Message.Msg: *snicker* wrong. The dazzling lack of success of Windows 8 give's us yet more reason to pursue desktop computer market share. Right we've only got 10% whereas with our system software advantages we should be closer to 25% (assuming 75% are either SAUs or cheap). Right now we don't have that yet. Further there are a number of other obvious extensions of Apple's product line. Some members of Apple's product line, most notably the Mini Server are obvious ways to improve a LAN including routed via unix and a hardware firewall as well as Mail, NAT, DNS, and other services that can be provided to a network via the Mac Mini Server. These products need to be pushed more as they are often far more stable solutions than Unix/Linux workstations since they share the same common base source code. I can think of MANY reasons for Apple to Grow, and very few for them to shrink.

Message.Title: Why AAPL Should... / Why AAPL Shouldn't... (blah, blah, blah)
Message.Msg: Google the worlds "Why APPL should" or conversely "Why AAPL shouldn't" and see the tons and tons of high grade manure piled up over the years on the internet. Everyone has an opinion and everyone thinks they know what is best for the company. And everyone thinks they know what the future holds for AAPL. I can't remember a company that inspired that type of reaction from the investing public. There have beens lots of polarizing companies but none where even the casual observer in five minutes believes himself to be the best steward of corporate governance. Maybe it was the whole Steve Jobs cult thing... But the most surprising thing about all those opinions is how often they turn out wrong. Remember before AAPL brought out the iPhone how there were naysayers saying that the cell phone industry had too many entrenched players and that cell phones were already commoditized. Then when they saw the iPhone it changed everything. The cell phone became the smart phone and history was rewritten. So the point here is that the whole argument is simple: Based on every investing metric, AAPL is a bargain at these prices. Based on all the psychological criteria, it is a steal. If that old Buffet dictum of "be greedy when others are fearful" holds true, then this is definitely the time to buy. There couldn't possibly be a worse attitude to APPL as an investment right now. The pitfall is that this is indeed a value trap. AAPL is stuck making smartphones, iPods, computers, and tablets. That's it. It's over. They'll never make anything else revolutionary. Ever. (Does that sound reasonable? It shouldn't based on AAPL's track record) So that's where the lines are drawn. Value trap or golden opportunity. Take it or leave it.

Message.Title: Honest review of IPHONE vs Samsung S3
Message.Msg: I have been using the Galaxy S3 for 4 months now and I truly dislike this phone. My reasons are well know but So called the AAPL haters do not want to accept these facts. Just read it and maybe it will save you money that overly hyped S3 is truly not an Iphone equal or better. Good luck with your investments. The volume button is at the opposite side of the on/off button - you will constantly shut off the phone while adjusting the volume. It is a big problem especially in the middle of the phone conversation. The undo button is live when you're using the phone especially with the camera - your slightest touch will kick you out of the mode you're in. Especially if you are trying to catch a special moment. Extremely frustrating. Again the hidden settings button is live when the phone is on and your finger will touch this one constantly and the Setting will pop over what you're doing. Because of it's size, one hand hold and text is impossible - you must use both hands at any given time. The colors and and the tones are extremely saturated - not natural like the iphone - so your red and blue tones will look completely unrealistic. If you like taking pictures like I do you'll not like the camera. The menu button is made so cheaply that it gets stuck inside the housing. It's a cheaply made plastic phone to be honest. Fits and Finishes are just okay. CNBC application is a TOTAL JOKE. Ask the ones who use it. It's a hateful app and CNBC does not even care to make it better. Most of the apps are WATERED DOWN apps with no ease of use like the Iphone. App store is a complete joke. Another joke is the Music Store - ask the ones who use. That is an android problem for all android phones anyways. Galaxy S3 is a total hype and nothing special. When the street hates "a" company with a bashing from the Korean competition the stock thumbeled like it did. If you have the money and patience, you might have a big profit opportunity. S3 won't do that for sure!

Message.Title: The View From South Korea
Message.Msg: I live here in South Korea, the heart of Samsung, and I can tell you that there are plenty of Macs, iPhones, and Macbooks wherever you go. Even in the small town of Hongseong where I live, the local upscale Cafe Benne has to iMacs for customers to use. The APPL store traffic at the Coex in Gangnam has good traffic - customers trying the product and sales as well. Koreans do the Gangnam Style on their Mac products, too! I myself bought an iPod shuffle last week. Being new to the ecosystem, I had trouble getting the U.S. iTunes website. At first I thought it was a copyright issue but it was just that I was being redirected to the Korean website. I finally got on the iTunes store and downloaded T.I.'s "Paper Trail". My iPod sale will be recorded internationally and my iTunes download will be recorded domestically. Tell the truth, I'm actually quite happy with the Shuffle. And I found the $11 I payed for the TI album to be reasonable. This considering that I had tried to download for free from websites and pretty much discovered that they are all scams. In the end, you get what you pay for. And up to now I've found both the iPod and iTunes worth paying for. Maybe AAPL has lost one customer for the one they've gained in me. But at least they've gained a customer. And from what I can see on the streets here in South Korea, they are gaining even here in the heart of Samsung country.

Message.Title: I am a die in the wool long but I knew this was coming here's why
Message.Msg: Appl sat all alone on the innovation mountain with no other products coming close to them with the inception of the Iphone and Ipad. Now that the market at the high end has been saturated the market is saying what they always do eventually to all leaders "What have you done for me lately". It doesn't matter that AAPL continues to have great sales and were able to maintain their pad dominance with the mini because the aura of invincibility has been stripped from them and they now have to once again re-invent themselves as the innovation pioneer. Perception, though totally irrational, has become reality and appl must conquer another market to get it back. They need a product that rivals the ipad and iphone that can command the admiration of critics and capture the imagination of consumers. They can get back to the 500's easily with a nice dividend increase or even approach 600 again with a China Mobile deal and a new low end phone for the third world masses. But if they want to get past the Steve Jobs legacy of Genius and move back to a growth stock multiple of 13 to 15 they must change the perception to Sir Johnny Ives is Steve Jobs alter ego and the innovation arm of the company is in good hands. This can only be done with something new in a new category. IMO that area is the television which would open up a new avenue of growth and tie the iphone and ipad into an indispensable appendage to the upwardly mobile household. It fits together like a glove but apple has to include the cable companies because that is where people are willing to add a new expense for the convenience of easy use and utility. The cable companies are resistant because they saw what apple did to the music industry and they don't want to cede their power. Cook has to channel his inner Jobs and force his way in by hook or #$%$. The problem is I'm not sure he has it in him. How Cook manages to dominate the home entertainment centerpiece called the televsion will seal the fate of apple investo

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: AAPL is finally reacting to the proliferation of negatives that momentum traders were ignoring late last summer and into the fall. The value of Apple's distributable cash plus its top-of-the-heap brand image account for an immeasurable but very large percentage of its market capitalization. As a stock, it competes with other, "safer" companies such as Procter & Gamble (PG) with much higher P/Es but limited growth potential. Apple, however, helped to create the PC market and essentially created the modern smartphone and tablet markets. These, in aggregate, are secular growth markets. And of course, who knows what disruptive innovation in a new product or market, or important upgrade to existing products, the "Crazy Ones" in Cupertino have coming soon? This upside optionality is not going away any time soon.

Message.Title: Did Apple wait too long to install a rear view mirror?
Message.Msg: When you are the market leader, you dictate flow. Apple had this leverage for a few years wi the IPhone. When you are in this position you don't validate or react to competition, until you recognize they are credible, and pose a treat to your dominance. The tipping point of recognizing this is the key to maintaining market dominance. My sense is Apple may have waited to long to install the mirror....... And in doing so underestimated the viability of the Far East competitors. Now instead of dictating, they are reacting.......and the number of alternatives in the smartphone space is growing. But there is a silver lining, with so many smartphone products, the consumer is going to be confused, and may default the Apple Brand.

Message.Title: Why Everyone Should Own Wells Fargo
Message.Msg: Mar 3 2013, 10:44 | 4 comments | about: WFC, includes: BAC, C, JPM, USB Disclosure: I am long WFC. (More...) Wells Fargo & Company (WFC) is a play on the market regaining confidence in the banking sector, as well as investing in one of the best run banks at a bargain valuation. Despite having spent most of my career in New York in the financial industry, I confess that I rarely purchased financial stocks. They were simply never that cheap pre-crisis, and having started my career at a prop desk at an investment bank, I knew firsthand that banks were run for the benefit of the employees, not the shareholders. Some may dispute this, but when 50-60% of revenue goes to employees via comp, and 10-20% to the shareholders, it doesn't take a genius to realize that top management knows where its bread is buttered. Sure, stock options and stock grants were always awarded to incent the masses, but back in the day, these percentages were low, say 10-20%. Anyway, since the financial collapse in 2008/2009, banks continue to be a sector much maligned by the investing world. Concerns of diminishing Net Interest Margins (NIM), onerous regulations & future Basel III requirements, and weak loan demand continue to dog this group. Nevertheless, the best bank stocks perform well in good times, and in bad. In Wells Fargo's case, the company has performed admirably for the past 5 years (or decades for that matter). At its core, Wells Fargo is a "compounder." This is why Buffett continues to buy Wells Fargo, and why it is Berkshire's (BRK.A) biggest position. Berkshire now owns 8.7% of the company. What do I mean by compounder? Simply that cash returns on equity continue to not only be positive in bad years, but also high and impressive in arguably mediocre times like today. This is a stock that will continue to grow earnings and compound its book value/share, regardless of the cycle, as cash continues to roll into the bank's vaults.

Message.Title: Apple Could Get Healthy with a Meaningful Acquisition!
Message.Msg: Samsung is nipping at Apple's heels & may wind up swallowing their legs if they don't wise up! I recently found this story & believe that Apple could use its huge cash hoard to buy into healthcare & grow into a whole new area of technology. Merck and Samsung Bioepis Enter Biosimilars Development and Commercialization Agreement. Under the agreement, Samsung Bioepis will be responsible for preclinical and clinical development, process development and manufacturing, clinical trials and registration. Merck will be responsible for commercialization. Samsung Bioepis will receive an upfront payment from Merck, product supply income and will be eligible for additional payments associated with pre-specified clinical and regulatory milestones. Further financial terms were not disclosed. “Samsung Bioepis has been building the capabilities needed to develop high-quality biosimilars,” said Christopher Hansung Ko, Ph.D., CEO of Samsung Bioepis. “With this development and commercialization agreement, Samsung takes a significant step toward becoming a major player in the biopharmaceutical industry.” Samsung Bioepis, a joint venture between Samsung Biologics and Biogen Idec, aims to develop affordable and high-quality biopharmaceutical and biosimilar products. Samsung already has the lead on connecting us to our home through their appliance manufacturing facilities & they could become the leader in healthy connectivity as well. Anyone with ideas on what Apple could do in the healthcare arena & home connectivity?

Topic.Title: What would you do if you're Tim Cook?

Message.Msg: I would acknowledge that I might have undermined shareholders by not allocating cash more in their favor. I would also back up my words (feel their 'pain") by taking solid action-not weeks or months from now but right away-to avert further pain and suffering on the part of retail investors. Let's not forget that, for months, he's been talking and talking about a more proactive cash policy and yet nothing has panned out. I would also give stronger hints as to why growth at Apple, as many media talking heads would like you to believe, has not screeched to a halt, as opposed to making vague statements like we have "great stuff" coming. A more active engagement will slow down rumor-mongering and wild speculation regarding the company's state of affairs. I'd also work hard to inspire confidence in investors by showing that I'm running a tight ship. In short, I'd be more proactive and prone to creating catalysts to improve the company's reputation, operations and stock value. (In the mind of many, the erosion of stock value is equivalent to diminshing quality of their products.) Of course, we all assume that Tom Cook's job is a piece of cake and any one of us could do it.

Topic.Title: What would you do if you're Tim Cook?

Message.Msg: take a look at the 5 year chart to see the bubble swell and pop in just one year. ceos have little control over market cap especially if several hundred billion were created and lost in about a year. so the market pumped aapl up and now shorted it down. you'd have cause to worry if there were huge mistakes or problems with apple. but name a company that wouldn't trade balance sheets with apple. which company in your portfolio has more money in the bank and better brand recognition? 1. cook needs to cut a deal with china mobile but not hurt the existing deals. remember chinese are not americans. they shop different. chinese consumers are extremely price sensitive. cook needs to get china mobile in the fold but not at the expense of paying china mobile to carry the iphone. 2. what's reasonable? cook and management already does that and will do more. in the coming months cook will probably raise dividend. if you are a short term investor why should cook reward you? 3. but this is the fool's way of buying back shares. buy a lot then when you are done, then announce that you've bought. there's no need to tell the market that apple has set a buy back price. 4. innovation is the only way forward. apple engineers have been working very hard at this and will continue for the foreseeable future. by not spending too much and saving more, apple has bought itself some time to hit a few foul balls before the next homerun.

Message.Title: iWatch 3 years away?
Message.Msg: Rumors about Apple making a watch were going strong until the CEO of Corning said it could take 3 years for companies to learn how to deal with rolls of glass. Much of the media / blogs assumed that meant Apple is 3 years away from making a watch. The problem with that is the display on the watch wouldn't be flexible. Due to other components in the watch it's very unlikely to see a flexible screen anytime soon, but that doesn't mean you won't see an Apple iWatch with a curved display. LG already has flexible displays ready to go and if Apple wanted to use a flexible glass they could go with LG, but that doesn't mean the screen will be flexible. I expect Apple will release an iWatch later this year. Picture an iPod Nano with curved glass and features that connect the watch to your iPhone.

Topic.Title: Apple Could Get Healthy with a Meaningful Acquisition!

Message.Msg: steve jobs drew up a few plans for innovative health care devices before he died. only a few people have seen these drawings, including job's biographer. i suspect mossberg knows about these plans as well. healthcare would be a great place for apple. there's no other industry i can imagine that needs more innovation, better end-user design and experience, better engineering and design than health care. there's also a ton of money in health care, a ripe and prime market for apple to enter. perhaps apple can make a more comfortable breathing device, more comfortable blood pressure monitor, a better designed hospital bed that can use minor gestures to contact nurses and doctors to easily communicate how you are feeling. right now hospitals still use buzzers. what about a touch screen detailing what you need from a nurse? how much would you pay to be more comfortable during your weakest most vulnerable moments? steve jobs had a lot of time thinking about the next new products during his 2 year fight with cancer. jobs knew cook wasn't a products guy per say so worked very hard with cook and ives to build a pipeline of new products for the next few years. jobs ideas aren't spent yet. he still has a few products up his sleeve that may transform yet another industry.

Sure AAPL making money, More than just about any other company but whats going on here is the Big money sees a end to all the money that aapl's been getting as subsidized for their one time "only game in town" phone. Now thier are other options out there and apple will more than likely get a lower price in the near future for "the rights" to sell their phone. Hell yeah but how many other great companies have we also seen get treated like a step child for no more than uncertainty? Yeah in a way i am short but if i had it to do over? Meanwhile 100% disabled vets without any other ratings get less per month than I get in Social Security (I maxxed my contributions by the time I couldn't work anymore). Tell me, how does a paraplegic (remember most disabled vets get disabled young and never get a chance to EARN social security, and many don't have multiple ratings) is supposed to survive on $2000 or so a month? So we put the disabled vet at the poverty level by default. He actually qualifies for less benefits that someone who'd been born with a disability and lives in a group home. If the veteran is rated 100% due to unplayability rather than actual disability (e,g, they're so weird'd out they can't work) then they get a whole $1000 a month. About two Apple shares. People do NOT join the Army and get rich unless they invest ALL their disposable income (which in the early years is virtually ALL your income), buy properties wherever you are stationed and rent them out when you're not there, and make seriously wise investments. Message.Title: Mar 1st: China Mobile preps for iPhone with TD-LTE service
Message.Msg: China Mobile preps for iPhone with TD-LTE service by Steven Sande Mar 1st 2013 at 6:30PM The wait for an iPhone may finally be over this year for customers on the China Mobile TD-LTE network, reports Patently Apple. China Mobile confirmed at Mobile World Congress in Barcelona this week that it will be running tests of its TD-LTE network in more than 100 cities in China, which will provide fast data service to a potential customer base of more than 500 million people. The news follows reports that Apple supplier Qualcomm is producing a new solution that supports all available LTE implementations and that would allow phone manufacturers to provide a single mobile device that would provide global LTE roaming support. If Apple chooses to use this solution -- which also provides more efficient use of battery power -- in an upcoming iPhone, it could open the door to even more dynamic growth in

Message.Title: TAIPEI (AFP)--Taiwan's TPK Holding Co., a leading manufacturer of touch screens for Apple, will invest up to NT$30 billion (US$1.01 billion) this year to meet robust demand for mobile and other devices, media reported Sunday.
Message.Msg: Mar 3, 2013 03:34:08 (ET) TAIPEI (AFP)--Taiwan's TPK Holding Co., a leading manufacturer of touch screens for Apple, will invest up to NT$30 billion (US$1.01 billion) this year to meet robust demand for mobile and other devices, media reported Sunday. The capital will be used to raise production on the island and in China's coastal Fujian province, company chairman Michael Chiang said while breaking ground for a new plant in central Taiwan Saturday. Its existing research and development unit in Taiwan will also be expanded, he said, according to the Economic Daily News and the Commercial Times. The company's touch screens are used in smartphones, tablet PCs, notebook PCs, electronic books and other consumer electronic items.

Message.Title: Finance Professor sold at 600 and was a bull
Message.Msg: Notable finance professor Aswath Damodaran has also long been an Apple bull, except the academic guru sold his shares nearly a year ago in April 2012, somewhere in the range of $600 per share. This exit is particularly notable because Damodaran had originally bought Apple way back in 1997 (the same year that Steve Jobs would return to the company) and sold after 15 years of loyal ownership. To be clear, Damodaran had not lost his faith in the underlying business or what should really matter. Far from it. In fact, he constructed a discounted cash flow model at the time that valued Apple at $710, which proved to be rather prescient, as nearly six months later shares would top out at $705 -- within 0.7% of his estimate. Even though he considered shares undervalued at the time, they were less undervalued than normal. No, what Damodaran lost faith in were his fellow Apple

Message.Title: The Only Reason an Apple Bull Would Sell
Message.Msg: This is a great article by Evan Niu that discusses the irrationality related to investing in/trading aapl. No one could have said it any better. He paints a topsy-turvy world in which fundamentals and future growth take a back seat to investor emotions, all ceaselessly perpetuated by unscrupulous and frivilous news media. He makes a vague reference to Apple, the company, but there's no doubt in my mind that the management is facilitating and reinforcing these irrational tendencies by maintaining a culture of secrecy and not taking adequate steps to crush these irrational forces once and for all.

Message.Title: Apple Inc. (AAPL)’s BOD Receive Restricted Stock Worth Over $230K
Message.Msg: Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)’s Board of Directors, except CEO Tim Cook, received 562 restricted stock units as part of an automatic grant, according to a filing with the US Securities and Exchange commission. The shares at present are worth over $230,000. The names of the board of directors are as follows: Arthur D. Levinson, Bill Campbell, Millard Drexler, Albert Gore Jr, Robert A.Iger, Andrea Jung and Ronald D.Sugar. All these directors received 562 restricted stock units on Wednesday worth around $232,000. As per the transaction Form 4 documents of SEC, the restricted shares are part of automatic grant as mentioned in the 1997 Director Stock Plan and will vest on Feb 1, 2014. According to the reports, a notice regarding the compensation given to the executive was posted on Apple’s website on February 6, in which it was briefly mentioned that the board members’ retainers start at $50,000 per year. There was, also , a new corporate governance rule, which requires top line executive to hold the company’s stock worth at least triple their basic salary. The shares of Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) dropped to a 52 week low of $439.88 on January 25, 2013. A report from BGC, advice Investors to move towards equity options to gain most from the possible upside moves of the stock. A possible dividend increase during the earning release in mid April along with the possibilities of new product launch can act as a catalyst for the stock. In the shareholder meeting on February 27, 2013, Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) said that there is some great stuff in the pipeline, and the company is in active discussion about its use of cash. The shares of Apple can possibly move upward following the possible new product launch, but there are still cautious tones over its March Quarter result, says the report. Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) CEO stated at the shareholder meeting on February 27, 2013 “We have some great stuff coming” and “is in very, very active” discussions regarding its cash. Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) is also seeking to roll out more expensive iPads, which would hurt the average selling price, and it is possible that the interest and sales of the iPhone 5 is declining at a faster rate than expected.

Message.Title: Share Price, Stock Splits and Investor Psychology
Message.Msg: The Motley Fool article that came out today was actually quite good. It made it painfully obvious that AAPL is moved by the big money crowd chasing momentum. It has nothing to do with valuation. They say a stock split would make no difference but I disagree. Cheaper share price would allow more buyers in, especially retail investors that can't buy as many shares. It would also lift the psychological barrier that a high share price creates. People like to not only hold large numbers of shares, but also like to think they are buying at a cheap price. Imagine someone buys 2 shares of AAPL for $430 each. If the stock splits 4:1, then they buy 8 shares for about $108 each. Mathematically, it's still the same $860 of AAPL stock. But psychologically it's different. In the second case, the investor thinks they are getting more for less. Don't believe me? Go check out the NOK boards. The investors over there buy at $4 hand over fist and think they are getting a bargain on a company flirting with BK. It goes down 50 cents and they don't even blink and it encourages them to buy more. After all, it's only 50 cents a share, right? Even though that 50 cents may represent 20%, psychologically it makes it easier for them to stomach the paper loss. At the same time they'll say AAPL is tanking even though they are taking worse percent losses. In the end, AAPL is only down 35% or so. If the stock had gone from $7 to $4.30 it would not look or feel the same as if it goes down from $700 to $430. The magic of price psychology. Split the shares and the price of AAPL will head back up easy.

Message.Title: Stock Buyback Defense
Message.Msg: Additional evidence as to the incompetence and thorough lack of confidence Apple has in it's own company. The lack of a stock buyback defense. Apple has stated they initiated a $10 Billion stock buyback. If they believed in themselves why would they not be doubling down at $430 rather than let the stock slide? Simple, they know they have nothing and since their company is worthless they must maintain a large cash stockpile to avoid destruction. Any semi-competent company with a stock taken out to the woodshed like this would initiate a massive buyback defense at these levels. Currently has 938 Million float. Up a buyback to 100 Billion say over 3 years takes that float down roughly by 100 Million shares. If Apple believes their stock is underpriced, that type of buyback gets rewarded in spades with a huge bounce. If Apple does not believe in their own company then they should not put up and does not look like they will make a defense of their stock. Therefore current target price with no defense and a clean breakthrough of $435 means $350 as near term bottom with $300 a likely target by the end of the year. There is nothing stopping this downhill runaway train.

Message.Title: News
Message.Msg: TAIPEI (AFP)--Taiwan's TPK Holding Co., a leading manufacturer of touch screens for Apple, will invest up to NT$30 billion (US$1.01 billion) this year to meet robust demand for mobile and other devices, media reported Sunday. The capital will be used to raise production on the island and in China's coastal Fujian province, company chairman Michael Chiang said while breaking ground for a new plant in central Taiwan Saturday. Its existing research and development unit in Taiwan will also be expanded, he said, according to the Economic Daily News and the Commercial Times. The company's touch screens are used in smartphones, tablet PCs, notebook PCs, electronic books and other consumer electronic items.

Message.Title: trading aapl from novice to novice
Message.Msg: Kudos to all of the good honest folks on this board who share both the good and the bad. I am true novice at investing, but would like to share my simple opinion for those interested. I hope those of you who are new may be benefit. The market is a master of psychology. It knows exactly when guys like us panic. Give yourself a fair window to see if an investment pans out. Novices have no ability to time a market. It's insane to sell AAPL right now. Know that everything in print is 6-9 months behind, especially in tech. We average folks have almost no relevant info on AAPL outside of last quarters numbers and most critically- what we see. To try to analyze their market and next steps in futile. What I see are AAPL stores still packed with people and multiple friends continuing to convince me to buy my first MAC. What I hear is people anxious and excited to hear what their next product is. With all due respect to Samsung and other Asian players, they just don't have the imagination to compete. Asian brands are have no soul and don't captivate customers. No one aspires to be them. Everybody wants AAPL. Even now, there's the Ipad, and then everybody else. I have been loading up on AAPL 2014 450 options over the past week and let's just say I like my chances. This is the world's greatest brand. I'll take it at a discount anyday. I'm not let the #$%$ in NYC squeeze me out.

Message.Title: Nokia the most mentioned brand at MWC 2013
Message.Msg: "Lumia a bigger brand than Windows Phone" "It seems Nokia is rapidly Samsunging Windows Phone, with the vendor dominating the mobile OS to such an extent that the OS will soon become relatively irrelevant." "Media company Lissted did some analytics on the chatter on twitter during the 5 days of Mobile World Congress, looking at 7,260 tweets by 619 journalists, bloggers and analysts and 419 media outlet accounts tracked by Lissted that mentioned “MWC”, “MWC13”, “MWC2013” or “Mobile World Congress” during the week prior to the show and during the show itself (00.00 GMT-18/2/13 to 11.36 GMT-28/2/13)." "The analysis found Nokia with its Lumia handsets virtually dominated coverage of the show, being ahead even of Samsung (who was not present at the event) and showed Nokia it can generate journalist excitement even with its low-end offerings." "This is of course good news and bodes well for the potential success of these handsets." "Less good news for Microsoft is that while Lumia clocked in at position 9, Windows only managed position 13, and Microsoft itself 50, showing a separation has occurred between the two brands." "Less one think this was only a MWC phenomena, a look at Google Search Trends show the Lumia brand quickly overtook Windows Phone, and that the search volume between the two has just separated more and more in time." "In many ways this is hardly surprising, with Microsoft doing much less promoting for Windows Phone than Nokia has for its Lumia brand. It should however be a warning for Microsoft – Buyers are not picking up Lumias because they run Windows Phone, and were it nor for Nokia’s rather precarious financial position Nokia could as easily release an Android Lumia and buyers may not even blink."
